Award.AwardTitle: IBSS: Towards an Integrated Understanding of Natural Resource Use and Management

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary research project will examine variations in the ways that different human societies have managed natural resources. Scientists long have debated how environmental, demographic, institutional, social, and historical factors shape the natural resource management strategies used by different societies and why these strategies change over time. Diverse natural resource management approaches have allowed humans to inhabit every continent on earth, including such varied settings as deserts, rainforests, savannas, tundra, mountains, and plains. The degree to which society can use and manage resources sustainably is a primary determinant of current and future well-being. This project will provide global-scale empirical tests of possible answers to critical questions in long-standing debates regarding the geography and evolution of land tenure and subsistence strategies. The investigators will demonstrate the utility of approaches developed in biogeography and evolutionary biology for addressing theoretical issues from multiple disciplines regarding drivers of global geographic patterns in natural resource management. Project findings will provide policy makers and others with critical insights about the constraints and opportunities different contexts offer for more sustainable planning. The project will demonstrate the utility of a global, publicly accessible, interdisciplinary database developed by the investigators to facilitate studies of cultural diversity and other dimensions of resource management and use. The project also will valuable interdisciplinary education and training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students for for post-doctoral researchers.

The investigators will address three critical questions: (1) To what degree do different factors determine subsistence strategies and land tenure systems across different regions of the globe? (2) Do predictable patterns of change exist, or can any form of subsistence or land tenure turn into any other form over time? (3) Do subsistence strategies and land-tenure systems co-evolve? Consideration of these questions has been difficult due to the limitations of prior analytical approaches. The investigators have demonstrated the utility of methods originally developed in biogeography and evolutionary biology to explore the factors that drive the evolution and geographic patterns of cultural diversity, and they have assembled a database that maps more than 100 cultural features onto language family trees for over about 1,400 societies. They will link these data with data on ecological and environmental variables in order to conduct new inquiries into the drivers of cultural change and patterns of cultural diversity. This project is supported through the NSF Interdisciplinary Behavioral and Social Sciences Research (IBSS) competition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The diversity of natural resource management approaches has allowed humans to inhabit every terrestrial biome. However, mismatches between natural resource management and context can lead to devastating societal collapses. What remains unclear is how different social, cultural, historical, political and environmental factors shape natural resource management systems.

Our project explored two aspects of natural resource management systems: how humans get food (i.e., subsistence strategies) and how humans own land. Our team tested long-standing hypotheses from multiple disciplines regarding how and why subsistence and land ownership vary over space and time. In order to undertake these studies, which span the globe and thousands of years, we needed to compile large amounts of data. Our project contributed to the expansion of D-PLACE (Database of Places, Language, Culture, and Environment), a publicly available and expandable web-portal that maps cultural features onto language trees , which depict the evolutionary relationships among languages. The database also links these cultural and language data to ecological and environmental variables, empowering future research into the drivers of cultural change and patterns of cultural diversity for over 1400 human societies. Our team combined the power of the new database with analytical methods originally developed in biogeography and evolutionary biology to conduct empirical tests of theories regarding the geography and evolution of subsistence strategies and land ownership.

Humans use diverse strategies to obtain food, including hunting, fishing, or gathering wild flora and fauna. Theories also suggest that changing subsistence strategies may be difficult as it may require new technologies, social institutions, or knowledge systems. However, despite long-standing debate, little agreement exists about the influence different environmental and social conditions have on subsistence choices in different places and at different points in time.  

Our project explored these debates in five ways: First, although some have argued that unique conditions and events determine subsistence in each location, we found a limited set of environmental, social, and historical factors explained the vast majority of variation in subsistence from one part of the globe to another. Second, we developed new models that hindcast population densities back 20,000 years. We used these models to show that despite the timing of agricultural origins varying by thousands of years in different regions, in each case the pre-existing conditions of improving environmental conditions and higher population densities occurred when agriculture first arose. Third, we showed that, even after centuries of cultural evolution, the degree to which a society relies on farming continued to be predicted by the opportunities environments provided to the first species of plants and animals that humans domesticated. Fourth, we found different pathways that shape levels of social inequality in human societies. These pathways vary in the degree to which environmental conditions, subsistence strategies, wealth transmission across generations, and population sizes directly or indirectly influence social inequality. Fifth, we developed a theoretical framework to guide future study of the diversification of fermented foods over time and space in human societies.

How humans own land also varies widely, including systems with no ownership, and ones in which groups, kin, or individuals own land. Changes in land ownership systems may have profound implications for the degree to which different resources can be sustainably managed. But what factors determine the system used in a given location and how these systems change over time? We found that land ownership norms among Bantu societies in Africa, similar to those in Austronesian societies in the Pacific, likely evolved on a strict trajectory, but not necessarily one that involved stepwise increases in exclusivity of ownership as prior theory had suggested. We also explored drivers of geographical patterns of land ownership. Our global scale analysis found more land ownership in mountainous environments (where land ownership may make it easier to defend more patchy resources), when societies live at higher population densities, and when neighboring societies also practiced ownership. We found less support for previously proposed links between subsistence strategies and land ownership. Overall, we demonstrated the value of combining analytical approaches from evolutionary biology and ecology to test diverse hypotheses on the evolution and geographical patterns of human cultural diversity. 

The project produced multiple peer-reviewed publications, and we presented our results at academic conferences. The project also further grew an international and interdisciplinary network of researchers that has made critical advances in combining theory and methods from multiple disciplines to gain a better understanding of human history and cultural diversity. The project also contributed to the development of early-career scholars, by providing interdisciplinary training and career mentorship to postdoctoral fellows, as well as students who worked on the team as research assistants.
